text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with the beef Merlot
it's like beef Burgundy or beef
bourguignon only with Merlot so here we
go we're going to use a beef chuck and
don't buy stew meat buy a chuck roast
that's about 2 and 3/4 pounds just cut
it in cubes and then you can throw away
the fat and you can make it the size you
want it's just better ok you're going to
save a couple bucks a pound so do not
buy stew meat you don't know what that
stuff is we're going to salt and pepper
generously and then in a very hot Dutch
oven in some vegetable oil you're going
to sear that until it's nicely browned
on all sides do not worry about the
bottom getting too Brown because when we
deglaze that with wine it's going to
make the sauce have this beautiful color
while the meat is browning I'm going to
cut up one large onion I'm going to
remove the meat and I'm going to throw
in the onion and just let it sweat a
little bit in there I'm going to add a
pinch of salt and a tablespoon of butter
and then I'm going to put in two
tablespoons of flour and I'm going to
cook that for just three or four minutes
and the onions are going to soften a
little the flour is going to cook a
little by the way the dark brown on the
pan is from the meat juice not the flour
so don't let the flour burn but it won't
in just a couple minutes all right
as soon as that is cooked for like I
said three or four minutes I'm going to
put in half a bottle of red wine and I'm
using Merlot you use whatever you want
no cooking wine of course
alright so half a bottle of wine is
there's 750 milliliters which if you
divide that by 2 what's that
375 and if you divide that by 30 it's
like 2 cups or you just put in a half a
bottle wine then I'm going to reduce
that by about 1/2 that's going to take
about 10 minutes
all right the flour the roux there we
made is going to thicken that up a
little bit I'm going to add two carrots
that I chopped in like 1-inch pieces a
couple ribs of celery I cut up all right
I'm gonna throw that in I'm going to add
my beef back in with any accumulated
juices I'm going to give it another
pinch of salt and we can adjust that
later
a bay leaf and I'm going to tie some
fresh thyme sprigs together that's just
so I can pull them out and don't have to
fish the stems out and I'm just going to
cover that with two cups of beef broth
you're probably not making homemade beef
broth I didn't eat it for this so use an
all-natural low-sodium high-quality pay
the extra dollar no generic beef broth
that may or may not be made out of beef
use something nice we're going to bring
that up to a simmer or to cover that
just let that simmer for an hour and a
half on very low so now our and a half
later that's looking good now you see
that how it's barely bubbling the meat
is almost tender it's not perfectly
tender yet so I'm going to leave this
uncovered and I'm gonna let it simmer
and bubble away for another half hour
and you see right there the sauce got a
little thicker the meat is not perfectly
tender our vegetables are nice and
tender and look at that sauce
all right so shiny and just beautiful
and luxurious all right make sure you're
going to taste and adjust your seasoning
and I know what you're thinking you
forgot to put in the potatoes no I
didn't all right this beef Merlot is so
beautiful I don't want to mess it up
with a bunch of chunks of potato so what
I do I make some beautiful buttery Yukon
Gold mashed potatoes these were actually
garlic mashed potatoes make a little
well I spoon the beef stew in there to
me that is just the best of all worlds
you get that nice beautiful fluffy
potato underneath the succulent
fall-apart beef the slow cooked
vegetables beef bourguignon beef
Burgundy very old-school recipe this is
a version of that called beef Merlot
because you know there's more of a
chance you'll make beef Merlot than beef
bourguignon give that a try go to this
site and you'll have all the ingredients
there and as always enjoy
you
